I.  INTRODUCTION 
 
1.  The knowledge and support technical assistance (TA) will help enhance the development 
capacity of the civil aviation sector in Bhutan by formulating a civil aviation strategy and providing 
advisory work and hands-on support to the executing agency and respective stakeholders.1 The 
TA will have three outputs: (i) civil aviation sector strategy plan report prepared; (ii) regulatory, 
operational, and institutional capacity enhanced; and (iii) knowledge management and capacity 
building improved.2 
 
2.  This TA is included in the country operations business plan for Bhutan, 2020–2022 and 
its objective is identified as one of the three pillars in the country partnership strategy, 2019–2023: 
to improve connectivity by supporting sustainable investments and know-how to upgrade air 
transport structures and services for a more reliable and efficient movement of people and goods.3  
 
II.  ISSUES  
 
3.   Air transport in Bhutan. Bhutan is a landlocked, mountainous country that presents 
unique challenges to the development of transport infrastructure, including air transport. Despite 
these challenges, continuous development in the sector remains a key priority to accommodate 
the ever-increasing air transport demand. Between 2013 and 2018, the annual passenger traffic 
in Bhutan increased at an average of more than 10%. This is partly attributed to the government’s 
effort to accelerate tourism development in the country, and the introduction of domestic air 
transport services, which enhances access to tourist attractions in outer regions. In 2018, Bhutan 
registered more than 397,000 international passengers, an increase from about 314,000 in 2017.4  
 
4.  Civil aviation is essential for Bhutan’s growth. It provides vital support to the development 
of tourism as well as to trade and manufacturing. Because of Bhutan’s geographical features, the 
domestic air transport network has been crucial in linking the capital city of Thimphu in the western 
region with administrative and commercial centers in the central, southern, and eastern regions. 
Four airports facilitate these linkages: an international airport in Paro, which also caters to 
domestic flights, and three domestic airports in Bumthang, Gelephu, and Yonphula.   
 
5.  Paro  International  Airport.  The  Paro  International  Airport  (PIA)  is  Bhutan’s  only 
international airport and is used by most international visitors to enter the country. The airport 
provides air transport facilities and passenger services to two operators, the national carrier 
Drukair and the private airline Tashi Air. Inclement weather conditions sometimes disrupt the 
PIA’s air transport operations, with safety regulations requiring aircrafts to divert to other regional 
international airports. The mountainous terrain restricts the PIA’s physical expansion. Constrained 
by limited operational hours, the PIA runway’s peak capacity is seven aircraft movements per 
hour. Under this scenario and with annual passengers estimated to reach over 900,000 by 2030, 
passenger volume will exceed the PIA’s ultimate capacity by 2033.5  
 
 
1  The stakeholders are the Department of Air Transport (DoAT) and the Bhutan Civil Aviation Authority (BCAA), from 
Ministry of Information and Communications of Bhutan. 
2  The Civil Aviation Act of Bhutan, 2016 defines civil aviation as the operation of any civil aircraft for the purpose of 
general aviation, aerial work, or commercial air transport operations. Commercial air transport operations are defined 
as aircraft operation involving the transport of passengers, cargo, or mail for remuneration or hire. 
3  ADB. 2018. Country Business Operations Plan: Bhutan, 2020–2022. Manila; and ADB. 2019. Country Partnership 
Strategy: Bhutan, 2019–2023—Fostering Diversification and Reducing Disparities. Manila. The TA first appeared in 
the business opportunities section of ADB’s website on 1 October 2019. 
4  Royal Government of Bhutan, Department of Air Transport. 2019. Passenger statistics (internal). Paro. 
5  ADB. 2010. Air Transport Connectivity Enhancement Project. Consultant’s report. Manila (TA 7633-BHU).

2 
6.  Air transport in Bhutan also plays a pivotal role in providing aid during  emergency 
response or disaster relief. The country’s vulnerability to natural hazards and climate change is 
high and adaptation measures are an absolute necessity. Moreover, the rising air traffic demand 
has put additional pressure on the country’s air transport sector, including its institutional aspect. 
The capacity of the Department of Air Transport (DoAT) and the Bhutan Civil Aviation Authority 
(BCAA) to effectively manage the country’s aviation sector, especially airports, is constrained by 
limited funds and lack of a comprehensive sector strategy that includes short-, medium-, and long-
term action plans. The government’s current Civil Aviation Master Plan, approved in October 2004, 
defined, emphasized, and documented the need for a well-developed air transport system in 
Bhutan up to 2030. 
 
7.  Institutional and regulatory framework. The civil aviation sector of Bhutan has been 
restructured and has adopted several reforms since 2009. The Civil Aviation Act of Bhutan, 2000 
was updated in 2016 and currently serves as the instrument to regulate and administer civil 
aviation in the country. The separation of regulatory and operational functions of the Department 
of Civil Aviation took place in April 2015. As a result, the BCAA serves as a regulator while the 
DoAT serves as an airport operator.6 The DoAT reports to the Ministry of Information and 
Communications and is responsible for ensuring safe, regular, and effective operation of flights, 
air communication, navigation, and transportation services for both domestic and international 
services.  
 
8.  Government strategy. In line with the country’s vision statement, the Government of 
Bhutan developed and subsequently endorsed the Twelfth Five Year Plan, 2018–2023 in 2018.7 
The plan identifies national key areas as development outcomes that will address priority national 
issues. The sustainable development of the tourism sector and the enhancement of climate and 
disaster resilience capabilities were recognized as key factors that support balanced social and 
economic growth. To enable these national development efforts, the air transport system and 
services  are  to  be  further  improved  by  increasing  operational  capacity,  effectiveness,  and 
efficiency. Therefore, the government is considering expanding and scaling up the capacity of the 
existing domestic airports (Bumthang, Gelephu, and Yonphula), including measures to enhance 
responsiveness to natural disaster and climate change risks.  
 
9.  Upgrading existing domestic airports. Gelephu is located in southern Bhutan, about 30 
kilometers east of Sarpang, the district (dzongkhag) headquarters. Because of its flat terrain and 
topographical conditions, the DoAT considers Gelephu’s domestic airport the most feasible for 
potential upgrade and for operating as an alternate airport to PIA. The Government’s Twelfth Five 
Year Plan, 2018–2023 identifies the expansion of Gelephu airport as a key activity of the country’s 
program to improve air transport system in the country. The plan also recognizes Gelephu as a 
regional growth center that will improve socioeconomic development in Bhutan’s outer regions 
and further enhance access to regional markets because of its proximity to India. This is also in 
line with the Bhutan National Urbanization Strategy and the Gelephu Structure Plan, which identify 
 
6 ADB. 2011. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Strengthening Air Transport Regulatory and 
 
Operational Performance. Manila. Under this technical assistance, the legal and regulatory provisions of the civil 
aviation sector in Bhutan were strengthened. By successfully separating the regulatory and operational functions of 
the Department of Civil Aviation between the DoAT and BCAA, any conflict of interest in their roles and responsibilities 
was eliminated. Both departments were able to manage their own staff, which helped the staff recruitment and staff 
retention. The reliability of the civil aviation sector in Bhutan was also enhanced by operating under international 
standards.  
7  Royal Government of Bhutan, Gross National Happiness Commission. 2018. Twelfth Five Year Plan for the Kingdom 
of Bhutan 2018–2023. Thimphu.

3 
an extended urbanization project and the development of manufacturing, trade, transport, and 
industrial facilities as the upcoming activities for the town and for the district.8 
 
10.  ADB contribution to Bhutan’s civil aviation sector. ADB has been involved in the 
development of the civil aviation sector in Bhutan through two TA projects and one grant project 
(including additional financing). Approved in 2010, ADB’s first project preparatory TA to the 
Department  of  Civil  Aviation  helped  formulate  the  ensuing  Air  Transport  Connectivity 
Enhancement Project.9 The project, which is still ongoing, aims to enhance capacity and security 
at the Bumthang, Gelephu, and Yonphula domestic airports.10 A separate TA focused on building 
civil  aviation  capacity  and  improving  air  transport  regulatory  and  operational  performance 
(footnote 6). Inadequate capacity of the executing agency, the DoAT, in procurement and contract 
management was identified as the key issue during project implementation, for which hands-on 
support from ADB consultants was provided.  
 
11.  With ADB’s involvement, the physical and institutional capacity of the sector has improved 
considerably to accommodate the rapid growth of air traffic since 2004. The long-term objective 
of enhancing the air transport system is also in line with the Bhutan Transport 2040 Integrated 
Strategic Vision, prepared with ADB’s support in collaboration with the Government of Australia 
through the Australian Agency for International Development.11 ADB’s engagement in the sector 
is based on the commitment to address the challenges of air connectivity and to improve access 
to external trades to ensure future economic growth and disaster preparedness.  
 
12.  The TA will help the government formulate a comprehensive national civil aviation sector 
strategy that incorporates sustainable development principles to meet the air transport demand, 
solve the existing operation constraints, and enhance emergency responsiveness. The strategy 
will also recognize the need to expand air transport services to other international hubs and 
regional centers and for an alternative arrangement for the PIA. The TA will support the DoAT to 
review and confirm the feasibility of expanding Gelephu against the other two domestic airports 
in Bumthang and Yonphula and prepare a master plan for upgrading Gelephu that will reflect the 
government’s current plan and priorities.  
 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
13.  The TA is aligned with the following impact: civil aviation sector in Bhutan improved 
(footnote 7). The TA will have the following outcome: planning and preparation for enhancement 
of air transport services in Bhutan improved.12 
 
 
8 1Royal Government of Bhutan, Ministry of Works and Human Settlement. 2008. Bhutan National Urbanization 
Strategy. Thimphu; and Department of Urban Development and Engineering Services, Ministry of Works and Human 
Settlement. 2005. Gelephu Structure Plan. Thimphu (Approved by the National Consultation Committee on Human 
Settlement). 
9 ADB. 2010. Technical Assistance to the Kingdom of Bhutan for Air Transport Connectivity and Enhancement Project.     
Manila (TA 7633-BHU). 
10 ADB. 2012. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Air Transport Connectivity 
Enhancement. Manila; and ADB. 2016. Report and Recommendation of the President to the Board of Directors: Air 
Transport Connectivity Enhancement—Additional Financing. Manila. 
11 ADB. 2013. Bhutan Transport 2040 Integrated Strategic Vision. Manila. 
12 The design and monitoring framework is in Appendix 1.

4 
B.  Outputs, Methods, and Activities 
 
14.  Output 1: Civil aviation sector strategy plan prepared. The TA will help to: 
(i)  conduct an assessment of the civil aviation sector in Bhutan, including reviewing 
and analyzing sector planning data, technical information, environmental and 
social  data,  technical  studies,  operational  and  maintenance  capabilities,  the 
institutional and legal framework, and financial information; 
(ii)  examine the infrastructure capacity of the four airports in the country in air traffic, 
technical characteristics, financial situation, and climate change risks, and develop 
an investment plan based on this examination;  
(iii)  formulate a sector strategy with a short-, medium-, and long-term outlook to 
increase capacity and enhance operational safety, factoring in climate change 
risks, country vulnerability, and regional developments; and 
(iv)  assess the feasibility of expanding Gelephu airport to upgrade to international 
standards,  specifications,  and  regulations  and  enhance  Bhutan’s  emergency 
resilience. 
 
15.  Output  2:  Proposal  for  regulatory,  operational  and  institutional  capacity 
enhancement  prepared.  The  TA  will  help  the  government review  current regulations  and 
administrative and executive instructions; assess the possibility of enabling an environment within 
which the DoAT and/or the private sector can provide safe and effective services to operate the 
airports; and prepare a regulatory, operations, and institutional report. 
 
16.  Output 3: Knowledge management and capacity building improved. The TA will 
improve the existing limited knowledge and skills of the DoAT and the BCAA by following a hands-
on learning process through seminars, workshops, or other knowledge-based programs in areas 
such as planning for economic and social development, climate change risks, disaster and climate 
change resilience, environment and social safeguards, air connectivity strategy, or private sector 
operations. This will be conducted throughout the TA implementation, from the formulation of the 
civil aviation strategy to the elaboration of the master plan. 
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
 
17.  The TA is estimated to cost $2,100,000, of which $2,000,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-6). The key expenditure items are 
listed in Appendix 2.  
 
18.  The government will provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff, office 
space for the consultants, access to data and information for the international and national 
consultants, staff time to review outputs of consultants, and other in-kind contributions equivalent 
to $100,000.  
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
 
19.  ADB  will  administer  the  TA  and  be  responsible  for  the  selection,  supervision,  and 
evaluation of consultants. The executing and implementing agencies of the government will 
provide counterpart support in the form of counterpart staff and other in-kind contributions. They 
will also provide available technical feasibility studies and designs, data and information access, 
and facilitate liaison with stakeholders; and will guide the implementation of the TA to achieve the 
TA outputs and desired outcomes within the agreed implementation period.

5

21.  Consulting services. ADB will recruit a firm using quality- and cost-based selection with 
a 90:10 quality-cost ratio and full technical proposal. ADB will engage consultants and carry out 
procurement following the ADB Procurement Policy (2017, as amended from time to time) and its 
associated project administration instructions and/or staff instructions.13 Consultants will procure 
goods and will administer consultations, workshops, and seminars under the TA budget. 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
 
22.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $2,000,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Bhutan for Enhancing Aviation Sector Development Capacity, and hereby 
reports this action to the Board.
 
13 Terms of Reference for Consultants (accessible from the list of linked documents in Appendix 3).
